tl;dr, we all know overwatch sucks, so just play indie games and support indie devs.

I spent 30 minutes on the menu screen of overwatch 2, so I could write this review. about 13 minutes of these 30 minutes in the verification screen, fumbling my way through the authentication process. I don't often need to use authenticator apps, so I was tasked with updating the authenticator app to instead the new and official battle.net app. When I logged into it on my phone, I needed to log into the battle.net application. Oooookay, no problem doing that, I guess. What's one more extra layer of security? So, I realize that my google passwords doesn't match my password for my battle.net login. So, I log into my other password manager on my pc, and I find the password there. Sounds good, we solved task number one! So, I attempt to log into the application on my phone again...only for it to ask for me to check my authenticator on my phone to approve of this login. I have to approve of the authenticator before I can use the authenticator app...okay, we're softlocked boys.

So, I go onto my computer to see if I can resolve the issue. Of course, I still have to approve of the usage of battle.net on my pc by using the authenticator application, which I can't use because I'm soft-locked...but I instead go through sms message and log in using that. I then remember that overwatch 2 required the usage of non-prepaid phones because of the  mandatory 2FA term that was passed. Kinda scummy, but not something that personally bars me from being able to play the game, since I do not have a prepaid. So, I get an idea--if I can log in using my sms code, then I can do the same thing on my phone, and solve the issue there! So, I log in with my phone finally, and enter into the new battle.net app. It's already confusing me, because I should see an option to scan using a qr code to enter into the game, but I just cannot find it. So, instead, I try to log into the game using the code on the left side...only for me to not find away to key in the code on the app either. And, finally, I realize that all I had to do to link my steam and blizzard account was by going to battle.net/link on my computer.

This long-winded story may seem like a contrived attempt at eking out competency from my rather incompetent usage of technology, and though this is partially true, I think the frustration from doing a lot of extra for something that is ultimately not worth the energy is something every Overwatch 2 player can, in some amount, share a sense of camaraderie in. Now, I can state the obvious gripes and grievances I have with the game--the gameplay isn't fun, the company is terrible, the business practices are apalling, or the free-to-play system only lends itself to milk more money out of the consumer. Each of these can all be retorted--depends on the player and no one demands you to play ranked, riot studios harassed their female employees first and NO ONE talks about it, and the consumer fed the monster that is microtransactions (NEEDLESS TO SAY, PAYING $20 FOR A SKIN IS DOWNRIGHT ABHORRENT). So, with this being the case, I don't see any reason to go through the hashed complaints that I am both not qualified to add any extra input in save for my own anecdotal experience, nor heated enough about the game to push through the drudgery that is even thinking critically about this game.

Because it is just that--a game. It's not fun. It requires a different breed of players to invest themselves into a competitive game and try to pull from it some sort of accomplishment that absolves the player of the guilt of having sunk hundreds, if not thousands of hours into a game like overwatch. I've only played for 180 or so hours, and I have never been higher than bronze DPS, but I feel utterly no shame in being able to admit either of these things. To rank higher, I'd have to play a game I don't enjoy, with players that also don't enjoy the game, read patch notes, follow dev blogs, and surround myself in complainers--complainers that know the game they love is dead, and the only way to make their voices heard is by complaining. That, or the trash players that are just mad because of a skill issue. I played hanzo, a lot of hanzo, mostly hanzo. I played bastion too, and to go back into playing those characters means I'd have to either sit in the training room if I did not want to play with players, or turn off my chat, refuse to join voice chats, to save my own mental. And that's just not fun. Oh, and now the battlepass requires for you to finish different tiers to get all the alternate skins for the mythic skin. Now that's just silly. Oh, and the pve mode costs 20 dollars to play, with 40 dollars if you want some skins. Very silly.

So, instead of being negative, or just making complaints, I want to inspire you, the reader, to think critically about the media you consume. AAA companies will continue issuing out these cash-grabs and money-stealing practices if you keep giving the game your money. Boycotting is only going to work if there is an alternative to the game that itches those scratches that playing overwatch does. Battleborn had a chance, but it died off for reasons. Gigantic didn't get enough support, but it was regarded as, in general, a fun game to play. So, instead, I ask you, reviewer, to please consider supporting indie devs. You want fun games? You have to do slightly more as a consumer and buy games...from other people. Shocking, I know. For what it's worth, the gameplay is fun, but not worth the effort of playing the game. That is the best way I can describe playing overwatch.

I have a boxed copy Overwatch sitting beside me right now that Blizzard made useless so they could produce another disgusting cash grab.  I could recite all the heinous acts that this company has taken after the acquisition of by Activision but I feel like I'd just be sounding off into the echo chamber.  So I'll simply say this.

The face and voice of Overwatch at the height of its popularity, Jeff Kaplan is no longer associating himself with Overwatch or Activision Blizzard.  So why should we?  There was a time when Blizzard had one of the most popular RTS games ever, not to mention the most popular MMO. WoW literally was a game that defined a genre for two decades.  That company that produced Starcraft and WoW would of never needed to come to Steam hat in hand to peddle their wares.  But here we are in 2023.  Come gather around and see how far the mighty have fallen.   Hope you're enjoying the reviews Kotick.  I hope you get crushed by that golden parachute when Microsoft yeets you out of the C Suite.

[h1]A word on Bias[/h1]

I've been playing Overwatch in all it's forms since the launch of Orisa. I grinded the competitive ladder, I played in scrub tournaments, watched many hours of pro matches from Apex through to the current season of the Overwatch League. It's been my go-to game for multiplayer for almost four years and I've put 1500+ hours into the game. So this is coming from someone who is deep in the weeds of gametime, and from someone whose sole interest is in the core PvP gamemodes. I also want to say upfront that for the first part of this review, I'm not going to talk about things outside of the game. That'll be in the latter part, so for an opinion on the core gameplay is all you need, the first bit is for you.

[h1]The Actual Game[/h1]

I mentioned that I have been a sweaty try-hard in Overwatch for a reason. This was probably the first multiplayer game that really managed to pull me in since I played Quake 3 back in the day. I had tried many other multiplayer games, dabbling in WoW, Counterstrike, Rocket League, and importantly: Team Fortress 2. Yet I've only 30 hours in TF2, not the stupid time I have in Overwatch. There's one main reason for this: Polish. The amount of detail that has been put into the simple act of moving a character around, of firing their weapons, of using their abilities, all of the nerdiest detail in making a player's experience of playing a game just sparkle is here. It was only in playing other shooters that I came to realise how good even things like the replay viewer, or the basic menus are.

I've also just realised that I haven't actually mentioned the gameplay. It's a team-based 5v5 hero shooter. It's the Team Fortress model with MOBA elements. Yet the true magic is in variety of different playstyles that comes from the various hero's kits. The game gives you a wide variety of playstyle options within each role, and is almost built around seeing how players can adapt to enemy tactics and strategy, as well as how these interact with the level design, where each map has it's own different gameplay emphasis. Some maps and modes favour slower, methodical strategies, while others emphasise verticality and mobility. And this is just the basic unranked quickplay modes. Ranked competitive, a rotating set of deviations in the arcade mode, as well as the workshop modes that have allowed for some really interesting variations of the core gameplay. (that's ingame workshop, not steam workshop support - although that would be rad to get that integration in the future)

This is all for a Free to Play game. Which means I get to talk about monetisation. [i]wonderful.[/i]

[h1]What isn't free[/h1]

This is the point where I'm going to start to touch on the external factors surrounding the game and why the review section looks like a Friday night in Frankston. Buckle your fuckles boyos, we're going in deep.

I'm going to counter my previous glowing positivity for a brief moment to point out a couple of things that I don't like about how the game is monetised. Putting heroes behind a battlepass is a net negative for the game. I understand that the characters can be unlocked through gameplay and a bit of a grind, but segregating core mechanics behind a paywall just harms the competitive integrity of the game. I also do think that some of the skins are egregiously priced, but that really doesn't bother me, as I don't care too much about cosmetics, or the "gotta catch 'em all" mentality that some mad completionists exhibit. Which brings me to the PvE missions, and where a lot of people are about to label me as a shill.

I've not played too much of the missions yet, but I do want to clarify something. I don't consider the PvE to be a core mode of Overwatch. It's a fun sideshow. Yet from some of the discussions I've had to endure surrounding the free to play update, it's almost as if people just assumed that it would part of said update. After some cursory research, I couldn't find any information where Blizzard said that the PvE would be free. If someone wants to point to an official statement that Blizzard said it would be free, go ahead, But I was following everything in the leadup to the addition of the number. Speaking of the number...

[h1]Hype and Player Expectation[/h1]

The number on the end of the title [i]is[/i] marketing guff. Marketing guff that I think came about from the Overwatch team's stubborn refusal to embrace modern game production methodology. They blindly kept an expansion/sequel development cycle, took more and more resources from the live game, and when reality came crashing down they had to commit to putting a number on the end of their game to justify their management mistakes. Make no mistake, this was just the free to play update. There's a reason why I've not called this game a sequel. It isn't a sequel, but an expansion pack.

Yet a lie takes two to do damage.

The amount of discussions I've been a part of where people have just blindly believed every single piece of marketing put out, who have supplemented said marketing with their own speculation, and then just went with their speculations as if it were reality, is astounding. Then when the update goes live, and reality doesn't match their fabricated fantasy world, they just turn around and torch everything, revelling in the vitriol they're spewing into the world. These people trusted a giant corporation to be honest. At some point, these people need to take responsibility for their own expectations. But it's not enough that they feel bad for falling for the hype train, others must suffer like they have. Feel betrayed by Blizzard? Fine. Go do something other than whinge like a child for almost 12 months.

[h1]Wrapping up[/h1]

Overwatch is probably one of the best shooters on the market in terms of the core gameplay and the sheer level of polish. It's a shame a part of the fanbase is insufferable.

然后就是犯下贪婪之罪的联赛官方臭名昭著的SBB曾经发表的不正当言论以及联赛官方不作为为现在奄奄一息的联赛打下不可磨灭的基础就像他们的母亲一样似有似无，将双标以及政治正确拉满，换了却是趋势的木琴和衰败的联赛，在此想对他们的犹如母亲般的联赛说一句好似 开香槟咯。
最后就是犯下欺君之罪的游戏官方，曾经画饼的pve模式各种技能树在后就像你们的母亲一样消失了，倒不如说根本就不存在，再到从ow变成ow2就像是一个青涩的少年变成了一个初生的孤儿，买断制游戏赚不了钱那就游戏免费内容付费，付费内容也正如你们的母亲一般名存实亡，各种东西被你们这些初生东西拿来炒冷饭，不如叫冷饭先锋2算了。
如果你问我，我会不会继续玩下去，我的回答是会，为什么？因为我是傻逼，我是一个不折不扣的傻逼，当我在steam下载那一刻我就是个纯纯的贱人，我能让自己不那么惭愧的方式就是肆意骂它，不要新人再被这个傻逼游戏以及暴雪欺诈，然后又一个人偷偷在屏幕前抹眼泪。为什么我眼中常含泪水，因为这暴雪的母亲变成雪飘进了我的双眼

最后，我真的想变成末日铁拳一拳曹飞暴雪所有人的妈
